description: From Middle English shroud, from Old English sċrūd, from Proto-Germanic *skrūdą. Cognate with Old Norse skrúð (“the shrouds of a ship”) ( > Danish, Norwegian skrud (“splendid attire”)).

entries.meaning: That which clothes, covers, conceals, or protects; a garment.
examples: swaddled, as new born, in sable shrouds

entries.meaning: Especially, the dress for the dead; a winding sheet.
That which covers or shelters like a shroud.
A covered place used as a retreat or shelter, as a cave or den; also, a vault or crypt.
examples: a vault, or shroud, as under a church

entries.meaning: (nautical) One of a set of ropes or cables (rigging) attaching a mast to the sides of a vessel or to another anchor point, serving to support the mast sideways; such rigging collectively.
One of the two annular plates at the periphery of a water wheel, which form the sides of the buckets; a shroud plate.
(astronautics) A streamlined protective covering used to protect the payload during a rocket-powered launch.

description: From Middle English schrouden (> Anglo-Latin scrudāre), from Middle English schroud (“shroud”) (see above).

verbs.description: shroud (third-person singular simple present shrouds, present participle shrouding, simple past and past participle shrouded)

entries.meaning: To conceal or hide from view, as if by a shroud.
examples: The details of the plot were shrouded in mystery.
The truth behind their weekend retreat was shrouded in obscurity.

entries.meaning: The branching top of a tree; foliage.

verbs.description: shroud (third-person singular simple present shrouds, present participle shrouding, simple past and past participle shrouded)

entries.meaning: (transitive, UK, dialect) To lop the branches from (a tree).
